column12: Total population (43,320,154) - outgoing refugees (5,835,418) as at 24 October 2023 + (1,006,060) people who moved back from abroad.
column20: The entire country is considered affected by the crisis since conflict escalation in February 2022. Ukraine's total surface area according to the World Bank is 603,550 sqkm.
column28: The total population is considered to be exposed to the conflict, therefore this number is the same as the total population. Total population (43,320,154) - outgoing refugees (5,835,418) as at 24 October 2023 + (1,006,060) people who moved back from abroad. Note: This figure has been updated back to the previous methodology after temporarily using IOM estimated population numbers.
column36: This figure represents the sum number of people affected as identified by HNO 2023. Note: the number of people affected was adjusted up from (21,328,025) because as per INFORM Severity methodology, the number of PIN cannot be higher than number of people affected as is the case in Donetsk and Khmelnytskyi oblasts.
column44: In October 2023, there were (5,835,418) refugees according to UNHCR as at 24 October 2023, (3,674,000) estimated IDPs, and (4,573,000) returnees according to IOM. This figure is calculated as per the ACAPS severity methodology, aggregating the total number of displaced population groups such as internally displaced people (IDPs) + incoming refugees, asylum seekers, and vulnerable migrants (others of concern) + returnees + people leaving the country (outgoing refugees and asylum seekers) (updated UNHCR data).
column52: Injuries in the last six months as at October 2023 (122 in Oct, 443 in Sep, 477 in  Aug, 605 in July, 445 in June, 466 in May). Figure was adjusted retroactively in October 2023 to include only last 6 months instead of total injuries logged since Feb 2022. Note: OHCHR states that the actual figures are considerably higher, however because information from some locations where intense hostilities have been going on has been delayed, and other information is still being verified at the time of publication. For example, Mariupol (Donetsk region), Lysychansk, Popasna, and Sievierodonetsk (Luhansk region), where there are allegations of numerous civilian casualties. The reliability is set as low for this reason. There is also a discrepancy in the sum of the segregated data per month and the total number of injuries since 24 February 2023 according to OHCHR; for example, the sum Feb2022-Sep2023 is (15,700) while the total figure in the September 2023 report is (17,748).
column68: Fatalities in Ukraine the last 6 months according to ACLED data (1 May - 20 October), related to the following event types: battles, violence against civilians, explosions/remote violence, riots, protests, and strategic developments.
column108: The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology, and using HN0 2023 figures. Note: level 3 is the sum of stressed level (13%) and severe level (52%) in the HNO 2023, therefore it is 65% of the total number of PIN (17,569,676) as provided by OCHA on HDX.
column113: State Statistics Service 01/01/2022 ; UNFPA 14/11/2022; UNHCR 24/10/2023 ; IOM 19/10/2023 ; OCHA 15/12/2023
column116: Level 1 = People exposed (38,490,796) - affected (21,379,432).  The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology: Level 1 = the number of people exposed minus the number of people affected. Note: the number of people affected was adjusted up from 21,328,025 because as per INFORM Severity methodology, the number of PIN cannot be higher than number of people affected as it is in Donetsk and Khmelnytskyi oblasts.
column124: The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology using HN0 2023 figures. Level 2 = people affected (21,379,432) - PIN (17,569,676). Note: the number of people affected was slightly adjusted up from (21,328,025) because as per INFORM Severity methodology, the number of PIN cannot be higher than number of people affected as it is in Donetsk and Khmelnytskyi oblasts.
column132: The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology, and using HN0 2023 figures. column140: The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology, and using HN0 2023 figures. Note: Level 4 is equivalent to the extreme level in the HNO 2023, therefore, it is 8% of the total PIN (17,569,676).
column148: The number was adapted following the humanitarian conditions INFORM Severity methodology, and using HN0 2023 figures. Note: Level 4 is equivalent to the extreme level in the HNO 2023, therefore, it is 27% of the total PIN (17,569,676).

column108:
Only Refugees and asylum-seekers and Migrants are considered PiN. The total population of the Refugees, asylum-seekers and migrants are among the most marginalized and vulnerable groups in Yemen and are largely dependent on external humanitarian assistance to meet their basic needs. To estimate the humanitarian conditions for the SI, we are applying IPC of food security phase classification of Ma’rib as it is the most sever classification in Yemen and because similarity as Ma’rib sever humanitarian condition is partially driven by the huge IDPs whose humanitarian condition would more resemble the conditions of migrants relatively compared to host community.

Thus, 19% are placed at Level 5, 30% are placed at Level 4, while the remaining placed at Level 3

This is a conservative under estimation as it only takes food security aspect in determining the humanitarian condition instead of a multi-sectorial humanitarian conditions.
